channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Turkey’s Erdogan Tries to Play Nice, After a Year of Bashing Europe
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, center, with President Beji Caid Essebsi of Tunisia at Carthage Palace near Tunis this week.
item.description: Throughout 2017, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey alienated onetime allies. But is diplomatic isolation encouraging a sudden change of heart?
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: At an Air Show in China, Drones, Not Jets, Are the Stars
item.media:description: Dozens of drones waiting to perform in a light show at Hannan General Aviation Airport in Wuhan, China, in November.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: China makes the world’s most popular drones. The country’s passion for unmanned flying machines runs deep — and starts at an early age.
item.dc:creator: LAM YIK FEI and RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: George Weah Wins Liberia’s Presidency, Unofficial Results Show
item.media:description: George Weah after casting his ballot in the second round of presidential elections in Monrovia, Liberia, on Tuesday.
item.description: Mr. Weah, the former soccer player making his third run for the presidency, was well ahead at the polls, election officials said.
item.dc:creator: CLAIR MacDOUGALL and HELENE COOPER

item.title: Cairo Journal: Bump, Tumble, Go Faster! In Egypt, Roller Derby is Real Life
item.media:description: Caroline Fadel Courdi, center, nicknamed Acroline, during a training session.
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.description: The women on the Cairollers, Egypt’s only roller derby club, say the sport’s bump and tumble help unleash their frustrations and offer a sense of empowerment.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: After St. Petersburg Explosion, Putin Orders Police to ‘Liquidate’ Terrorists
item.media:description: An officer investigating the explosion inside a supermarket in St. Petersburg that wounded about a dozen people on Wednesday.
item.description: Vladimir V. Putin, who is running for a fourth term as Russia’s president, has burnished his reputation for being tough on extremists.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Peru’s Pardon of Fujimori Condemned by U.N. Rights Experts
item.media:description: Relatives of victims of human rights violations during the tenure of President Alberto Fujimori of Peru, at a news conference in Lima on Wednesday.
item.description: Several aides to President Pedro Pablo Kuczynski have resigned in protest, and more demonstrations are expected.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA ZARATE and MARCELO ROCHABRUN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Islamic State Claims Deadly Blast at Afghan Shiite Center
item.media:description: The scene of a suicide bomb attack that killed dozens in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Thursday.
item.description: A suicide bomber struck a crowded gathering in Kabul, leaving more than 40 dead. The group has claimed several attacks on Shiite targets across the country.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED, FATIMA FAIZI and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Assad Must Go, Erdogan Says, as Syria War Winds Down
item.media:description: Syrian soldiers parade past a banner depicting President Bashar al-Assad during a government celebration in December 2017.
item.description: The denunciation appeared to be Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s effort to remind Russia, Syria’s most powerful ally, that it cannot dictate the country’s postwar future alone.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Ukraine Fighting Pauses, Briefly, for Big Prisoner Exchange
item.media:description: Prisoners of war from separatist self-proclaimed republics before boarding a bus during an exchange of captives near the city of Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Wednesday.
item.description: The Ukrainian military and Russian-backed separatists swapped captives from a conflict in eastern Ukraine that has been going on since 2014.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Airstrikes in Yemen Kill 68 Civilians in a Single Day
item.media:description: A funeral in Sana, Yemen, on Tuesday for people killed in airstrikes. The civilian death toll over the past two weeks is at least 109.
item.description: The United Nations said dead included eight children and 14 members of one family.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: China Offers Tax Incentives to Persuade U.S. Companies to Stay
item.media:description: A Walmart store in Beijing. The retailer is among the many American companies with a presence in China.
item.description: Following a tax overhaul in the United States, Beijing has announced a temporary exemption for foreign firms investing in certain sectors.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: South Korea Clamps Down on Bitcoin Trading Amid Market Frenzy
item.media:description: A restaurant in Seoul, South Korea, that accepts Bitcoin.
item.description: In one of the biggest hubs for virtual currencies, the government said it would no longer let people buy or sell Bitcoin or its rivals anonymously.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: In an Era of ‘Forever Wars,’ the Middle East Bureau Manager Who Made Our Coverage Possible
item.media:description: Jane Scott-Long leaned against a Soviet-era tank in Afghanistan in January 2002. Four foreign journalists had been ambushed and killed a few days earlier at the same spot on the Grand Trunk Road between Jalalabad and Kabul.
item.description: Reporters, photographers and security advisers came and went. Jane Scott-Long stayed.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Tibetan Filmmaker Flees to U.S. After ‘Arduous’ Escape from China
item.media:description: Protesters demanding the release of the Tibetan movie director Dhondup Wangchen protest outside the Chinese embassy in Tokyo in 2009.
item.description: The filmmaker was jailed for interviewing Tibetans about their lives under Chinese rule. His escape reflects a growing climate of repression in China.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Heads Up: Lake Como for a New Generation of Cool Kids
item.media:description: Il Sereno, a lakeside boutique hotel by Milan interior designer Patricia Urquiola, does not feign historic provenance.
item.description: Long a playground for Hollywood stars of a certain age, Lake Como is trying to attract a younger, hipper crowd.
item.dc:creator: SHEILA MARIKAR

item.title: Once a Cash Cow, Venezuela’s Oil Company Now Verges on Collapse
item.media:description: Residents of the fishing village Amuay waited for several hours to get their gas tanks filled. Deepening troubles at the state oil company threaten to further destabilize the nation.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The deepening troubles threaten to further destabilize a nation facing a dire recession and unbridled crime, as well as food and medicine shortages.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Health Care, Barack Obama, Jerusalem: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Tired of Regional Critics, Venezuela Looks to Russia and China
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, center, is increasingly regarded as a despot among neighbors in a region that has shifted politically to the right.
item.description: Once a regional heavyweight, Venezuela is losing allies in its region, causing it to deepen its dependence on China and Russia.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Israeli Minister Wants to Name a Jerusalem Train Station for Trump
item.media:description: President Trump at the Western Wall in May. A plan to name a proposed rail station after him has generated debate.
item.description: The proposed station would deposit tourists in the Old City, a few hundred yards from the Temple Mount.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER and IRIT PAZNER GARSHOWITZ

item.title: Tel Aviv’s Toy-Block Tower Measures Up for a Record
item.media:description: The tower in Rabin Square, in central Tel Aviv, on Wednesday. At 35.95 meters, or 117 feet 11 inches, tall, it is said to be nearly 3 feet taller than a previous effort in Milan.
item.description: Half a million toy bricks were used for the community project, carried out in memory of an 8-year-old who died of cancer.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Geely Buys Stake in Volvo Trucks, Despite China Restrictions
item.media:description: Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, which bought Volvo Cars in 2010, announced a deal on Wednesday that would make it the largest shareholder in AB Volvo, which makes trucks.
item.media:credit: James Silverman for The New York Times.
item.description: The government in Beijing has unveiled an array of new regulations to temper outbound investment. But Chinese companies are still going global.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: Rabwah Journal: Shunned by Pakistan’s Muslims, Ahmadis Find Refuge in a City of Their Own
item.media:description: An Ahmadi graveyard in Rabwah, Pakistan.
item.media:credit: Mohsin Raza for The New York Times
item.description: Rabwah, home to about 70,000 Ahmadis, has a veneer of calm, even affluence, that is at odds with the growing hatred against the sect elsewhere in the country.
item.dc:creator: MEHREEN ZAHRA-MALIK

item.title: Deal With Japan on Former Sex Slaves Failed Victims, South Korean Panel Says
item.media:description: A ceremony in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday to commemorate the deaths this year of eight women who were forced into sexual slavery during World War II.
item.description: The conclusions threaten the 2015 agreement over so-called comfort women, forced to work in brothels for the Japanese military from the 1930s until 1945.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: When Harry Met Barry: The BBC Obama Interview
item.description: The former president said he was adjusting to life outside the White House, and expressed concern, without naming names, about the possible corrosive effects of social media.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: ‘Nobody Thought It Would Come to This’: Drug Maker Teva Faces a Crisis
item.media:description: Workers protesting outside a Teva factory in Jerusalem this month after the company said it would lay off 14,000 employees.
item.description: The move by Israel’s corporate version of a celebrity to lay off 14,000 workers was greeted with outrage and a nationwide strike.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SEGAL and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Myanmar Court Extends Detention of Reuters Journalists
item.media:description: U Wa Lone outside court in Yangon, Myanmar, on Wednesday. He and another Reuters journalist were arrested Dec. 12 while reporting on Rakhine State, site of a military crackdown on ethnic Rohingya.
item.description: The arrests of two journalists covering Rakhine, the site of a brutal military crackdown on Rohingya, were criticized as an attack on press freedom.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Just Saying No: Luminaries Who Have Shunned Awards
item.media:description: Sacheen Littlefeather refused the 1973 Academy Award for Best Actor on behalf of Marlon Brando, who won for his role in “The Godfather.” The award was presented by Roger Moore and Liv Ullmann.
item.description: As the French chef Jérôme Brochot returns his Michelin star, here is a look at others who have turned down celebrated honors and awards.
item.dc:creator: TESS FELDER

item.title: North Korean Defectors Show Signs of Possible Radiation Exposure
item.media:description: South Korean scientists monitored seismic waves in September after the North conducted a nuclear test.
item.description: South Korea examined the health of North Korean defectors amid fears that nuclear tests may have released radioactive fallout.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: ‘We’re Competing Against Everybody Just Like You’: Voices on Manufacturing in Mexico
item.media:description: An assembly plant known as a maquiladora in Reynosa, a city in the the Mexican state of Tamaulipas, in 2014.
item.media:credit: Jennifer Whitney for The New York Times
item.description: As uncertainty continues over the fate of Nafta, we asked readers in the manufacturing industry in Mexico to share their views on globalization.
item.dc:creator: FARAH STOCKMAN and MICHEL VEGA

item.title: Chef Gives Up a Star, Reflecting Hardship of ‘the Other France’
item.media:description: The chef Jérôme Brochot, center, at his restaurant in Montceau-les-Mines, France.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Most chefs work a lifetime for a Michelin star. Jérôme Brochot is giving his back. Why? He can’t afford it. Neither can his declining old mining town.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Aide Accused of Playing Role in Death of Argentine Prosecutor
item.media:description: Diego Lagomarsino, center in a 2015 photograph, was indicted Tuesday on charges that he played a role in the death of an Argentine prosecutor investigating a possible cover-up related to a 1994 bombing in Buenos Aires.
item.description: The charges against a computer expert employed by Alberto Nisman, who was found dead in 2015, are the first time a judge has called the case a homicide.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI

item.title: Putin May Be Re-Election Shoo-in, but He’s Taking No Chances
item.description: First Aleksei A. Navalny, an anticorruption activist, was blocked from running for president. Then he was warned not to organize a boycott of the election.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Homeland Security, Uber, Peru: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Homeland Security Investigations
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Liberia Election Could Mark First Peaceful Transfer of Power Since 1944
item.media:description: People waited at a polling station in Monrovia, Liberia, on Tuesday, in a presidential runoff that pit a former soccer star against the vice president.
item.description: In a presidential runoff, voters are choosing between a soccer star, George Weah, and Vice President Joseph Boakai, to replace Ellen Johnson Sirleaf.
item.dc:creator: CLAIR MacDOUGALL

item.title: Saudi Arabia Blocks Israel’s Chess Team From World Championships
item.media:description: Vladimir Malakhov of Russia playing Vahap Sanal of Turkey at the King Salman Rapid and Blitz Chess Championships in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.
item.description: The team’s seven players are demanding financial compensation after being unable to obtain the visas they needed to attend the competitions.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: Egypt Hangs 15 for Terrorism, Stoking Fears Among Islamists
item.media:description: The Egyptian military near Cairo’s Tahrir Square in August 2013, a month after it had seized power.
item.description: The men were executed for an attack in 2013, at the start of an Islamic insurgency that the government has been battling ever since.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Homeland Security Goes Abroad. Not Everyone Is Grateful.
item.media:description: Agents with Homeland Security Investigations were part of a 2015 extradition in South Africa of suspects in a Nigerian fraud ring that is accused of cheating Americans out of $52 million.
item.media:credit: Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Homeland Security Investigations.
item.description: Set up to defend the United States, the Homeland Security Department is going beyond American borders to fight foreign threats from abroad.
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON

item.title: The Betoota Advocate, a Fake News Site Australians Really Love
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia with Clancy Overell and Errol Parker, the pen names for the founders of the satirical website The Betoota Advocate, at Parliament House in October.
item.description: Often compared to The Onion, the satirical news site has spun off a beer and clothing line. But has the voice of disenchanted millennials gone mainstream?
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: From a Hospital Bed, Alberto Fujimori Asks Peru to ‘Forgive Me’
item.media:description: Protesters gathered on Monday near the hospital in Lima, Peru, where former President Alberto Fujimori is being treated.
item.description: The former president made his first public statement since being released from prison on a medical pardon, acknowledging that he had disappointed his country.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA ZARATE and ERNESTO LONDOÑO
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Richmond Journal: In a Chinese Enclave of Canada, the Sweet Escape of Karaoke
item.media:description: “Sometimes you just want to sing, and then sing more,” said Karns You, 30, enjoying his time at Party World KTV in Richmond, a suburb of Vancouver.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: The city of Richmond, which is now majority ethnic Chinese, provides ample opportunities for crooners who want to let loose in multiple languages.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Royal Navy Escorts Russian Warship Near U.K.
item.media:description: The St. Albans, in the foreground, escorting the Russian warship Admiral Gorshkov through the North Sea.
item.media:credit: British Royal Navy, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: “Britain will never be intimidated when it comes to protecting our country, our people, and our national interests,” Defense Secretary Gavin Williamson said.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Global Health: Measles Deaths Fall to a Record Low Worldwide
item.media:description: A child receiving measles vaccine in a refugee camp in Bangladesh last month. Annual deaths from measles have fallen below 100,000 worldwide, according to the World Health Organization.
item.description: Thanks to vaccines, the disease — which not long ago killed over 2 million children a year — now kills fewer than 100,000, the W.H.O. reported.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Cross-Border Clashes in Kashmir Leave 7 Soldiers Dead
item.media:description: The funeral of a suspected Pakistan-based militant, who according to the local news media was killed in a gun battle with Indian security forces, in Kashmir on Tuesday.
item.description: On the same day Pakistan allowed an Indian accused of spying a visit from his family, three Pakistani soldiers were killed in Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Thousands Once Spoke His Language in the Amazon. Now, He’s the Only One.
item.media:description: Amadeo fishing near Intuto. The Peruvian Amazon was once a vast linguistic repository, but in the last century at least 37 languages have disappeared in Peru alone.
item.media:credit: Ben C. Solomon/The New York Times
item.description: The Taushiro tribe vanished into the jungles of the Amazon basin in Peru generations ago. Amadeo García García is now the last native speaker of their language.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Laundry Day Around the World
item.description: From handwashing to laundromats, people in different parts of the world gather together to do laundry. Enter those spaces in 360 video.

item.title: The Last Man to Speak His Language
item.description: Amadeo García García is the last man to speak Taushiro, a language spoken by an Amazon tribe. When he goes, an entire culture will disappear. We went to find him.

item.title: North Korea Won’t Stop Its Arms Tests Anytime Soon, South Korea Warns
item.media:description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, addressed a ruling party conference in Pyongyang, the capital, on Saturday, according to the state news agency.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: Government and private analysts expect the North to bolster its nuclear and long-range missile capabilities in 2018 to gain leverage with Washington.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: One Man’s Stand Against Junk Food as Diabetes Climbs Across India
item.media:description: Rahul Verma distributing the Indian dish khichdi, a mixture of rice, lentils and vegetables, to patients outside a hospital in New Delhi. Mr. Verma has taken a stand against junk food in India, where people are more likely to develop diabetes from weight gain than people in other regions.
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times.
item.description: India is “sitting on a volcano” of diabetes. A father’s effort to ban junk food sales in and near schools aims to change what children eat.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND
